verses.text: What then shall we say? Are we to remain in sin so that grace may abound?
verses.comment: Paul raises a crucial rhetorical question: does grace encourage continued sin? Some early heresies suggested this, but Paul will reject it outright.

verses.text: Certainly not! How can we who died to sin still live in it?
verses.comment: Paul affirms the radical change brought by union with Christ. To 'die to sin' means a real transformation, not just a legal declaration.

verses.text: Or do you not know that all of us who were baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?
verses.comment: Baptism is presented not just as a symbol, but as true participation in Christ’s death. Early Church Fathers saw a real spiritual effect here.

verses.text: Therefore we were buried with him by baptism into death, so that as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, so too we might walk in newness of life.
verses.comment: This verse connects baptism with Christ’s resurrection—that is, believers receive new, transformed life. Note the reference to the Father, highlighting the Trinity.

verses.text: For if we have been united with him in the likeness of his death, surely we shall also be in the likeness of his resurrection.
verses.comment: Union with Christ is not only about dying to sin but also sharing in his resurrection, a central hope in Christian faith.

verses.text: We know this, that our old self was crucified with him so that the body ruled by sin might be destroyed, so that we would no longer be slaves to sin.
verses.comment: The 'old self' refers to humanity under Adam (see Rom. 5:12). Through Christ, believers participate in a real moral transformation, not merely an external declaration.

verses.text: For the one who has died has been set free from sin.
verses.comment: In dying with Christ, we are liberated from sin's power, not just its penalty. Liberation here has present implications for Christian living.

verses.text: Now if we have died with Christ, we believe that we shall also live with him.
verses.comment: Participating with Christ's death assures us that we will share in his resurrected life—a promise for the future, but begun now in spiritual life.

verses.text: We know that Christ, having been raised from the dead, will never die again; death no longer has dominion over him.
verses.comment: Christ’s resurrection is permanent and victorious over death. This passage teaches the uniqueness and supremacy of Christ.

verses.text: For the death he died, he died to sin once for all; but the life he lives, he lives to God.
verses.comment: Jesus’ once-for-all sacrifice underlines its sufficiency and finality—contrasting the repeated Old Testament sacrifices.

verses.text: So you also must consider yourselves dead to sin but alive to God in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: The Christian life flows from our union with Christ—counting ourselves as belonging to God with a new identity. This is at the root of Christian sanctification.

verses.text: Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body to make you obey its desires.
verses.comment: Paul calls for active resistance against sin. The 'body' is a battleground—spiritual effort and growth are necessary for Christians.

verses.text: Do not present your members to sin as instruments for unrighteousness, but present yourselves to God as those brought from death to life, and your members to God as instruments for righteousness.
verses.comment: Paul uses sacrificial language, calling Christians to offer their lives to God. There’s an echo of Old Testament priestly service.

verses.text: For sin shall not rule over you, since you are not under law but under grace.
verses.comment: Grace, given by God, empowers obedience beyond the law. Christians are equipped by grace to actually resist and overcome sin’s mastery.

verses.text: What then? Shall we sin because we are not under law but under grace? Certainly not!
verses.comment: Paul forcefully rejects the idea that grace gives a license to sin. Rather, grace leads to real obedience and transformation.

verses.text: Do you not know that if you present yourselves to anyone as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one whom you obey—either of sin, which leads to death, or of obedience, which leads to righteousness?
verses.comment: Sin’s mastery brings spiritual death. True freedom comes only in the service of righteousness through obedience.

verses.text: But thanks be to God, that you who were once slaves of sin have become obedient from the heart to the pattern of teaching to which you were entrusted.
verses.comment: Notice obedience to a standard of teaching— the early community held to an apostolic tradition, handed down and received (see 2 Tim. 1:14).

verses.text: And having been set free from sin, you became slaves of righteousness.
verses.comment: True freedom is found in dedicating oneself to righteousness. This implies a visible change in life and behavior.

verses.text: I am speaking in human terms because of the weakness of your flesh. For just as you once presented your members as slaves to impurity and lawlessness leading to more lawlessness, so now present your members as slaves to righteousness for holiness.
verses.comment: Righteousness leads to sanctification—a process, not a one-time act. Human effort and cooperation with grace are both stressed here.

verses.text: For when you were slaves of sin, you were free in regard to righteousness.
verses.comment: Without Christ, a person has no claim to righteousness. 'Freedom' from righteousness is actually slavery to sin.

verses.text: But what fruit did you have then from the things of which you are now ashamed? For the end of those things is death.
verses.comment: Sin brings shame and ultimately death. This echoes the Old Testament’s teaching that sin’s wages are spiritual death (Gen. 2:17).

verses.text: But now that you have been set free from sin and have become servants of God, the fruit you get leads to holiness, and its end, eternal life.
verses.comment: The path of righteousness and holiness leads to eternal life. This verse suggests sanctification is necessary for final salvation.

verses.text: For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.comment: Paul summarizes: death as the natural result of sin, but eternal life as a free gift—received in union with Christ. Eternal life is the ultimate fulfillment of God’s promises.
